title: SSRF - Guard - Unchecked HKP servers

profile.name: Open-Xchange
profile.about: Messaging, collaboration and office productivity software for service providers

vulnerability_information:
## Description

When encrypting an email, one of strategies to lookup recipient's encryption key is to contact a HKP keyserver specified in DNS records of recipient's domain.

Specifically it is `DNS SRV` records for `_hkps._tcp.<domain>` and `_hkp._tcp.<domain>`, which specify hostname and port of the keyserver.

In source code it is implemented in `HKPRecipKeyLookupStrategy`, `SRVHKPClientService`, `RemoteHKPClientService`, `HKPClient` classes.

The problem is that a keyserver specified in DNS can be any server, including internal adresses. Also HKP(S) is just HTTP(S) protocol, so the SRV entry might look legitimate, but the HKP server iself can later redirect clients to any other address.

## Attack vectors

* Server user can trigger this directly
* External attacker can lure a server user to send them an encrypted email

## Steps to reproduce

Attached is a simple program {F712580} which implements DNS and HKP server.

* run my DNS/HKP server on nameserver for *<yourdomain>*

```bash
nameserver# python3 hkp-server.py MY.IP.AD.DR
```
* run netcat on appsuite server

```bash
appsuite# nc -lp 1234
```
* compose new email in OX App Suite
* enter any address with your domain as recipient's address - *user@<yourdomain>*
* click on `Enable Encryption` lock icon
* in terminal on nameserver you should see output like this

```
DNS _hkps._tcp.<yourdomain>.
DNS _hkp._tcp.<yourdomain>.
# answer to this ^^ will be hkp.<yourdomain>:80
DNS hkp.<yourdomain>.
GET hkp.<yourdomain>:80/pks/lookup?op=index&options=mr&search=user@<yourdomain>
# answer to this ^^ will be redirect to localhost:1234
```
* in terminal on appsuite you should see output like this, confirming the SSRF

```http
GET /badthing HTTP/1.1
accept: application/json
Connection: close
X-UI-INTERNAL-ACCOUNT-ID: d0a18490e9b982369e5a671a6c8a9263
Host: localhost:1234
User-Agent: Apache-HttpClient/4.5.7 (Java/1.8.0_232)
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
```

## Impact

An attacker can trigger requests to internal resources.
vulnerability_information_html:
Description

When encrypting an email, one of strategies to lookup recipient's encryption key is to contact a HKP keyserver specified in DNS records of recipient's domain.

Specifically it is DNS SRV records for _hkps._tcp.<domain> and _hkp._tcp.<domain>, which specify hostname and port of the keyserver.

In source code it is implemented in HKPRecipKeyLookupStrategy, SRVHKPClientService, RemoteHKPClientService, HKPClient classes.

The problem is that a keyserver specified in DNS can be any server, including internal adresses. Also HKP(S) is just HTTP(S) protocol, so the SRV entry might look legitimate, but the HKP server iself can later redirect clients to any other address.

Attack vectors

  • Server user can trigger this directly
  • External attacker can lure a server user to send them an encrypted email

Steps to reproduce

Attached is a simple program hkp-server.py (F712580) which implements DNS and HKP server.

  • run my DNS/HKP server on nameserver for <yourdomain> 
nameserver# python3 hkp-server.py MY.IP.AD.DR
  • run netcat on appsuite server
appsuite# nc -lp 1234
  • compose new email in OX App Suite
  • enter any address with your domain as recipient's address - user@<yourdomain>
  • click on Enable Encryption lock icon
  • in terminal on nameserver you should see output like this
DNS _hkps._tcp.<yourdomain>.
DNS _hkp._tcp.<yourdomain>.
# answer to this ^^ will be hkp.<yourdomain>:80
DNS hkp.<yourdomain>.
GET hkp.<yourdomain>:80/pks/lookup?op=index&options=mr&search=user@<yourdomain>
# answer to this ^^ will be redirect to localhost:1234
  • in terminal on appsuite you should see output like this, confirming the SSRF
GET /badthing HTTP/1.1
accept: application/json
Connection: close
X-UI-INTERNAL-ACCOUNT-ID: d0a18490e9b982369e5a671a6c8a9263
Host: localhost:1234
User-Agent: Apache-HttpClient/4.5.7 (Java/1.8.0_232)
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate

activities.message:
Thanks for the report, you're right that redirects to local resources should be avoided. 

Can you please describe the "External attacker can lure a server user to send them an encrypted email" case in more detail? To my understanding this would require the attacker to take over a legitimate domain, which allows a great number of other nasty things. Injecting incorrect public key information through HKP alone would probably make the mail useless but would not redirect it.
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for the report, you're right that redirects to local resources should be avoided.

Can you please describe the "External attacker can lure a server user to send them an encrypted email" case in more detail? To my understanding this would require the attacker to take over a legitimate domain, which allows a great number of other nasty things. Injecting incorrect public key information through HKP alone would probably make the mail useless but would not redirect it.

activities.message:
Hello,

I didn't mean taking over someone else's domain. Where I said <yourdomain> I meant that you will be just testing it on your domain. Otherwise I as an attacker would ask you as a victim to send me an email to my domain under my control. Then when Guard tries to fetch a key from my HKP server it would redirect the request back to your infrastucture.

It would be useful mainly if the attacker already knew that there is some HTTP-based (or HTTP-friendly) service in your infrastructure and the request would be somehow useful for them.

Also the code seems to be trying all SRV entries from the DNS response (which didn't work for me, but I didn't investigate it), so it could possibly cause chain of multiple internal requests, or at least maybe allow to measure times between requests for port-scanning or something.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello,

I didn't mean taking over someone else's domain. Where I said <yourdomain> I meant that you will be just testing it on your domain. Otherwise I as an attacker would ask you as a victim to send me an email to my domain under my control. Then when Guard tries to fetch a key from my HKP server it would redirect the request back to your infrastucture.

It would be useful mainly if the attacker already knew that there is some HTTP-based (or HTTP-friendly) service in your infrastructure and the request would be somehow useful for them.

Also the code seems to be trying all SRV entries from the DNS response (which didn't work for me, but I didn't investigate it), so it could possibly cause chain of multiple internal requests, or at least maybe allow to measure times between requests for port-scanning or something.

activities.message:
OK, thanks. So that specific attack vector would include social engineering to send a mail to a domain which uses malicious hkp responders. I understood that you could somehow use this lookup to "automatically" redirect mail without owning the domain or make the user do things.

The attack vector of using a domain under your control and redirecting HKP requests while having access to a account with Guard is clear and makes sense. We're going to follow up on this vector primarily.
activities.markdown_message:

The attack vector of using a domain under your control and redirecting HKP requests while having access to a account with Guard is clear and makes sense. We're going to follow up on this vector primarily.

activities.message: Thank you very much for the bounty.
activities.markdown_message: Thank you very much for the bounty.
